name: Dummy Deck
description: Sandbox for testing new technical phrases before migration.

cards.sideA: No quise llegar tan lejos.

sideB.text: I didn't mean to go that far.
I didn't intend to take it that far.
It wasn't my intention to go so far.
I didn't want to go that far.
I didn't want to go too far.
I didn't mean to go too far.

cards.sideA: ¿Quién está en la cima de la jerarquía?.

sideB.text: Who is at the top of the hierarchy?
Who stands at the hierarchy's summit?
Who is at the hierarchy peak?

cards.sideA: Necesitas respetar la jerarquía de la empresa.

sideB.text: You need to respect the company hierarchy.
You must respect the corporate hierarchy.
You have to respect the hierarchy of the company.

cards.sideA: Entran todos, a excepción del #45

sideB.text: Everything is included, except for #45.
All of them go in, with the exception of #45.
Every single one is coming in, excluding #45.

cards.note: [Everything] or [All of them] is used for objects. [Everyone] is strictly for people. Use [Every single one] when you want to emphasize each individual item in a set.

cards.sideA: Ya no estamos usando ese procedimiento.

sideB.text: We are no longer using that procedure.
We aren't using that procedure anymore.
That procedure is no longer in use.
We don't use that procedure any longer.
We no longer use that procedure.

cards.note: ~We no loger use that procedure~ is incorrect due to the spelling of [longer] and because the structure requires the adverb to be placed correctly relative to the verb.

cards.sideA: Decidí no actualizar el servidor esta noche.

sideB.text: I decided not to update the server tonight.
I chose to not update the server tonight.
I made the decision not to update the server tonight.

cards.note:
**[188]**

[Not to update] is the correct way to negate the secondary action 'update' after the main verb [decided].

cards.sideA: Él prefiere no recibir notificaciones por correo.

sideB.text: He prefers not to receive email notifications.
He prefers to not receive notifications by email.
He'd rather not receive email notifications.

cards.note:
**[188]**

In modern English, [to not receive] and [not to receive] are both perfectly acceptable and interchangeable.

~He doesn't prefers receiving email notifications~ is not valid because the auxiliary [doesn't] must be followed by the [base verb] 'prefer' (without the 's').

cards.sideA: Intenta no borrar los archivos temporales aún.

sideB.text: Try not to delete the temporary files yet.
Please try to not delete the temp files just yet.
Try to avoid deleting the temporary files for now.

cards.note:
**[188]**

~Try don't delete~ is a common error; always use [not to] or [to not] when negating an infinitive.

cards.sideA: Podemos usar o React o Vue para este proyecto.

sideB.text: We can use either React or Vue for this project.
Either React or Vue can be used for this project.
We have the option of using either React or Vue.

cards.note:
**[189]**

[Either... or] is the correct structure for presenting a choice between two available alternatives.

cards.sideA: Necesitamos una biblioteca para gestionar los popup.

sideB.text: We need a library to manage the popups.
We require a library to handle the popups.
A library is needed to manage pop-up windows.

cards.sideA: La biblioteca verifica la versión en la tienda.

sideB.text: The library checks the version in the store.
The library verifies the version on the app store.
This library is used to check for the store version.
The library verifies the version in the store.
The library verifies the version on the store.

cards.sideA: Esa biblioteca permite forzar la actualización.

sideB.text: That library allows forcing the update.
That library enables us to force an update.
That library makes it possible to force the update.

cards.note:
**[13]**



~That library allows to force~ is grammatically incorrect. The verb 'allow' must be followed by an Object + Infinitive ([allows us to force]) or a Gerund ([allows forcing]). It cannot be followed directly by 'to'.

cards.sideA: Debemos configurar la biblioteca en el proyecto.

sideB.text: We must configure the library in the project.
We need to set up the library within the project.
The library needs to be configured in the project.

cards.note: ~We must set the library~ is incomplete. In this context, you need the phrasal verb [set up] or the verb [configure]. 'Set' alone usually means to establish a value or place an object.

cards.sideA: La biblioteca muestra un mensaje de descarga.

sideB.text: The library shows a download message.
The library displays a message for downloading.
This library prompts the user with a download message.

cards.note: ~The library shows a downloaded message~ changes the meaning. [Downloaded] implies the message itself was retrieved from a server, whereas [download message] refers to a notification about a download process.

cards.sideA: Lo dejé ahí por si acaso.

sideB.text: I left it there just in case.
I kept it there in case I need it later.
I put it there just as a precaution.

cards.sideA: Dejé esa línea de código comentada ahí por si acaso.

sideB.text: I left that line commented out, just in case.
I kept that line of code commented there just in case.
I left that line of code as a comment there just in case.
I left that commented line, just in case.

cards.sideA: Me faltan 5 dolares.

sideB.text: I'm missing 5 dollars.
I'm 5 dollars short.
I need 5 dollars more.

cards.sideA: Me faltan algunos datos aun

sideB.text: I'm still missing some data.
I still lack some information.
Some data is still missing.
I still lack some data.

cards.note: ~I lack still some information~ has incorrect word order. The adverb [still] must be placed before the main verb: [I still lack].

cards.sideA: Son diferentes niveles de EBS.

sideB.text: They are different EBS levels.
These are various levels of EBS.
Those represent different levels within EBS.

cards.note: ~They are different leveles in EBS~ is invalid due to the spelling error in [levels].

cards.sideA: Así nos aseguramos que las fechas y mensajes en francés son correctos.

sideB.text: This way, we make sure the dates and messages in French are correct.
This ensures that dates and messages in French are accurate.
That's how we verify that the French dates and messages are right.
This way, we ensure the dates and messages in French are correct.

cards.sideA: Envía todos los datos solo en 1 llamada.

sideB.text: It sends all the data in a single call.
It transmits all the information in just one call.
All data is sent using only one request.

cards.note:
~It sends all the data just in one call~ sounds unnatural. The adverb 'just' should modify the quantity 'one', so the correct order is [in just one call].

~It sends all the data just in a single call~ is slightly awkward. The adverb 'just' should be placed right before the quantity it emphasizes: [in just a single call].

cards.sideA: En vez de hacer 3 llamadas, lo hacemos todo en 1.

sideB.text: Instead of making three separate calls, we handle everything in one.
Rather than performing three calls, we do it all in a single one.
We're processing everything in one go instead of three calls.

cards.sideA: Debemos establecerlo manualmente.

sideB.text: We must set it manually.
We have to configure it by hand.
It needs to be established manually.

cards.sideA: Este es el guardián de seguridad en el paquete.

sideB.text: This is the security gatekeeper within the package.
This acts as the security guard for the package.
This is the security gatekeeper inside the package.
This is the security guard in the package.

cards.note: ~This is the security guard of the package~ is grammatically correct but sounds a bit robotic. In technical English, using [for the package] or a noun adjunct like [package security guard] is more natural.

cards.sideA: Los datos y las fechas deben ser correctos.

sideB.text: The data and the dates must be correct.
Information and dates have to be accurate.
Data and dates need to be correct.

cards.sideA: Impide la fuga de información entre provincias.

sideB.text: It prevents data leakage between provinces.
It stops information from leaking between provinces.
It blocks data leaks across different provinces.
It prevents data leak between provinces.
It prevents data leakage among provinces.
It prevents the leak of information between provinces.

cards.sideA: Es un parser customizado desde inglés al francés.

sideB.text: It's a custom parser from English to French.
It is a customized parser for translating English to French.
This is a custom-built parser for English to French conversion.
It is a custom parser from English to French.

cards.sideA: Inicializa al usuario en EBS.

sideB.text: It initializes the user in EBS.
It sets up the user within EBS.
It performs the user initialization in EBS.

cards.note: ~Initialize the user in EBS~ is an imperative command (an order). Since the source sentence describes what the system does (Third Person), the correct form requires a subject: [It initializes] the user.

cards.sideA: Traduce el tipo de payment, ya sea en inglés o francés.

sideB.text: It translates the payment type, whether in English or French.
It handles the translation of the payment type into English or French.
It converts the payment type, regardless of it being in English or French.
It translates the kind of payment, whether in English or French.
It translates the payment type, either in English or French.
Translate the payment type, whether in English or French.
